      • setSupportedEncodings

        public static void setSupportedEncodings(java.util.Set<java.lang.String> encodings)
        Sets the supported character encodings for the MimeTypeDetector. When determining Mime type based upon content, MimeTypeDetector will interpret the content using the various encodings until it has found a match. For performance reasons, the Set of expected encodings should remain as small as possible. The JVM default encoding is automatically supported.

        The default set of supported encodings is "UTF-8", "ISO-8859-1", "windows-1252", and the current JVM default encoding.

        Parameters:
        encodings - a Set of canonical encoding names.
        See Also:
        Java Supported Encodings

      • getMimeType

        public java.lang.String getMimeType(java.lang.String filename,
                           byte[] content)
        Returns the MIME type for the document with the provided filename and/or content.

        If filename is provided, the file will not be accessed; however, the filename extension will be used for MIME type determination. For this reason, filenames that are extracted from ECMs, remote filesytems, even URLs (using URL.getPath()) should work. If filename is null, only the supplied content will be used to determine the MIME type.

        If content is provided, MimeTypeDetector will examine the first few thousand bytes of the content, looking for a match against a set of known character sequences found in common file formats. The caller need not supply the entire document content - only the beginning of the content is examined to determine MIME type, so the first 4 kilobytes of content is sufficient at this time. If content is null, only the filename extension will be used to determine the MIME type.

        Parameters:
        filename - used for filename extension MIME type detection (may be null)
        content - a byte array of document content used for MIME type detection (may be null)
        Returns:
        the most preferred MIME type for the document
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if both filename and content are null.

      • getMimeType

        public java.lang.String getMimeType(java.lang.String filename,
                           InputStreamFactory inputStreamFactory)
                             throws java.io.IOException
        Returns the MIME type for the document with the provided filename or content read from an InputStream.

        If filename is provided, the file will not be accessed; however, the filename extension will be used for MIME type determination. For this reason, filenames that are extracted from ECMs, remote filesytems, even URLs (using URL.getPath()) should work. If the MIME type can be determined solely by the filename extension, it will be returned.

        If the MIME type cannot be determined solely from the filename extension and inputStreamFactory is provided, MimeTypeDetector will get an InputStream from the factory and read the first few thousand bytes of the content, looking for a match against a set of known character sequences found in common file formats. If inputStreamFactory is null, only the filename extension will be used to determine the MIME type.

        Parameters:
        filename - used for filename extension MIME type detection (may be null)
        inputStreamFactory - an InputStreamFactory used to fetch and InputStream from which the document content may be read (may be null)
        Returns:
        the most preferred MIME type for the document
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if both filename and InputStreamFactory are null
        java.io.IOException - if there is an error reading from the InputStream
